S5.T1.caption: Table 1: Testing accuracy (%) on EMNIST and CIFAR-10 under δ=10−5𝛿superscript105\delta=10^{-5} and various privacy settings with three common σgsubscript𝜎𝑔\sigma_{g}. A larger σgsubscript𝜎𝑔\sigma_{g} indicates a smaller ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p}, i.e. the stronger privacy guarantee. ϑitalic-ϑ\vartheta stands for the scaling factor of the parameter λ𝜆\lambda. Three baselines are included: LDP-FedAvg which stands for FedAvg with local and user-level DP; PPSGD proposed by (Bietti et al., 2022); CENTAUR proposed by (Shen et al., 2023). For additional utility experiments, please refer to the Appendix 3 and 4.

references: In Table 1, our FedCEO demonstrates state-of-the-art performance under different privacy settings, aligning with the utility analysis in Section 4.1. Additionally, we can adapt to various privacy settings by flexibly adjusting the initial coefficient λ𝜆\lambda. Specifically, larger σgsubscript𝜎𝑔\sigma_{g} corresponds to smaller λ𝜆\lambda (lower rank, i.e. smaller r𝑟r). Moreover, our adaptive mechanism increases the truncation threshold (i.e. 12​λ​ϑtI12𝜆superscriptitalic-ϑ𝑡𝐼\frac{1}{2\lambda}\vartheta^{\frac{t}{I}}) as the Gaussian noise accumulates during the FL training process, due to the geometric series with a common ratio ϑ>1italic-ϑ1\vartheta>1. Refer to Appendix C.2.1, C.2.2 for experiments about model training efficiency and heterogeneous FL settings.

A3.T2.caption: Table 2: Our focused hyperparameters for three privacy settings on EMNIST and CIFAR-10.
references:
Hyperparameters.
For each dataset, we uniformly set the global communication rounds T𝑇T to 300, the total number of clients N𝑁N to 100, and the sampled client number K𝐾K to 10, resulting in a sampling rate p𝑝p of 0.1. Local training employs stochastic gradient descent (SGD) with 30 epochs (E𝐸E), a learning rate η𝜂\eta of 0.1, and a batch size B𝐵B of 64. Other personalized hyperparameters: initial coefficient λ𝜆\lambda, common ratio ϑitalic-ϑ\vartheta, and interval I𝐼I are listed in Table 2.

A3.T3.caption: Table 3: Runtime for our FedCEO and other methods on EMNIST and CIFAR-10 (One NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4090).
A3.T3.table:
Time / h LDP-FedAvg PPSGD CENTAUR FedCEO
EMNIST 5.436 >> 24 >> 24 5.445
CIFAR-10 3.876 >> 24 >> 24 3.908
references: To validate the efficiency of our server-side low-rank proximal optimization, we conducted a comparative analysis of the runtime between our FedCEO and other methods in Table 3. We observe that the training efficiency of our method significantly surpasses PPSGD and CENTAUR, approaching the efficiency of LDP-FedAvg without any utility improvement.

references: To validate the effectiveness of our model in heterogeneous federated learning, we conduct experiments using an MLP as the local model on CIFAR-10 in Table 4. We report the testing accuracy for both iid and non-iid 111non-iid means the data among clients are not independent and identically distributed (iid). scenarios. It can be observed that our FedCEO maintains state-of-the-art performance. Additionally, in non-iid scenarios, we typically choose a larger λ𝜆\lambda to reduce the global semantic smoothness, preserving more personalized local information.
